key_points: The White House is considering revising Section 230, which protects social media platforms from being held legally responsible for user-generated content.
White House Communications Director, Kate Bedingfield, highlighted the importance of accountability for social media companies spreading misinformation.
The debate over Section 230 has intensified as the administration urges platforms to combat misinformation more effectively.
President Joe Biden sees content creators as responsible, emphasizing the collective effort needed to combat misinformation.
Both Biden and former President Donald Trump have criticized Section 230, though for different reasons.
Trump's efforts to alter Section 230's application were deemed unconstitutional by legal experts and FCC officials.
Congress holds the power to amend Section 230, despite bipartisan agreement on the issue of regulating Big Tech.
Biden criticized Facebook for not doing enough to stop misinformation, retracting a previous statement that the platform was "killing people."
Senior officials are in contact with Facebook as tensions rise over the platform's handling of misinformation.
Biden urged Facebook to address the spread of false information about vaccines, referring to a report identifying main sources of anti-vaccine misinformation.
